div.l: Oure corn̄ is stole sothely it is no nay
And we haue had an̄ evill fit this day
And sithen̄ y shall haue none amendement
Ageyn̄ my lostis y will haue an̄ easement
By goddes feith it shall non̄ other be
This Iohn aunswerd · Aleyne avise the
The Millere is a ꝑperilous man̄ he seide
And yif that he oute of his slepe abreide
He myght do vs bothe a vilanye
Aleyne seide y counte hym̄ not at a flye
Vp̄ he arisith and to the wenche he crepe
This wenche lay vprighte and fast slepe
Till he so nygh was er she myght espie
That it had be to late for to crie
And shortly forto sey they were at on̄
Nowe pley on̄ Aleyn̄ and y shall speke of Iohn
This Iohn lieth still a forlong wey or two
And to hym̄ silf makith rueth and wo
Alas quod he this is a wicked Iape
Nowe may y say y am̄ but an̄ Ape
Yit hath my felawe somwhat for his harme
He hath the Millars doughtᵘur in his arme
He auntred hym̄ and hath his nede spedde
And y lie as a drafsacke in my bedde
And when̄ this Iape is tolde a nother day
I shalbe holden̄ a daff a Cokenay
Y wolle arise and aunter me by my feith
Vnhardy vnsely thus men̄ seith
And vp̄ he arose and softly wente
Vnto the Cradell and in his hand it hente
And bare it softe vnto his beddis fete
Sone aftʳur this wif hure rowtyng lete
And gan̄ a wake and went hure oute oute to pisse
And came ageyne and gan̄ hure Cradell misse
And groped here and there · and she founde none
Alas quod she I had almost mysgon̄
I had almoste gon̄ to the Clerkis bed
Ey benedicite then̄ had y evill sped
And furth she goth till she the Cradell fonde
And groped alway furth with hure honde
And founde the bed · and thought naught but good
